Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: Well - it won't stain this beautiful city with its abominations - not anymore.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Enough, Wulbren! Gortash enslaved us, forced us to build his Steel Watchers - but no more.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What about Gortash? What if he forces you to build up his Steel Watch once more?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: He'll never find us - we have safe-houses all over the city. We are no threat - I swear it.
("safe houses" as in "safehouses" for shelter)
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: Toobin will lie, torment, and scheme until his dying breath. Kill him - or the Ironhands will.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes.
Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill the Gondians, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Sorry, Toobin - I guess this is it for you.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.

Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?

Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.

Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.

Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
: True

Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.

Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?

Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Hello, sweetness.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I'm still waiting for someone with a spare eye...
Player: What happened to Mayrina? Did you do something to her?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I don't like busybodies.
Player: Did you have any trouble on the way here?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: None that I couldn't handle, precious.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I was hoping you'd pay me a visit. You see, I do more than lotions and potions.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: People in dire need travel from all over Faerûn to see little ol' me. And I do my damndest to help them.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: And you, petal - well, you need a lot of help.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: That wriggler swimming in your brain juice is a bit of an inconvenience, isn't it?
Player: Don't change the subject. Why is that woman really here?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I told you - the girl is none of your business. Keep that hole under your nose shut.
Karlach: I don't like this. What's really going on here?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I'll talk about your wriggler - and that's it. Last warning.
Player: I'll find another way to take care of it.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Yes, because everyone and their mother is an expert on illithid scum.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I can tell you're almost done cooking. You know you could turn - just like that.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: What do you say? Want me to take care of the little bugger?
Player: Yes. Get this damn parasite out of me.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: My - I do like them eager. But know that I don't work for free. I expect payment up front...
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: One of your pretty little peepers.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I'll pluck it from your head, kiss it for luck, then back in it goes. Won't take but a moment.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: That is my price. Nothing more, nothing less.
Player: You have a deal.

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above...
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: What are you doing out here? It's not safe.
Arabella: I was looking. For mum and pops. When Zevlor - when he -
Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm.
Arabella: Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: I'll find your parents - you can count on me.
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again!
Arabella: The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?

Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!

Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.

Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: CURIOSITY KILLED ALL THE CATS IT WON'T BE SO KIND TO YOU

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Ah the jailor will hear us. I shouldn't be talking to you. I must go. It's not kind to me.

Player: Maybe I can help you be free of whoever's hurting you.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I hope so. But it is a faint hope. Just like me.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I can't leave, I can only suffer. But I'm supposed to do that in silence. Everyone here hates me for what I am.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: This place must house our contract with Raphael. If Hope points the way, we might take it - and shred it.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: The House is home to many things. Most will kill you, one can save you. The Hammer - the Hammer that breaks the chains. You must steal it!

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.

Lorroakan: Mark my words: the Nightsong is mine. With or without your help, she will ascend to her grand fate here, in this tower.
Lorroakan: You can get very rich along the way, or let someone else take what's rightfully yours. Choose wisely.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap.
Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books.
Lorroakan: But enough of dusty history - I look to the future.
Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face.
Lorroakan: Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.
Lorroakan: Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him.
Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: Binding the Nightsong forever... How unoriginal. Need I recite the tale of Ketheric Thorm?
Player: A clever contraption. Let me guess: like Ketheric Thorm before you, you wish to become immortal.
Lorroakan: It didn't work out for poor Ketheric, did it? He was a fool. A desperate mercenary who whored out his soul to whichever god flattered him.
Lorroakan: I serve no god but that which stares back at me in the mirror.
Lorroakan: The Nightsong will be put to a grand purpose: equalising man and god. Whoever helps me attain that which I seek will be greatly rewarded.
Player: I've always dreamt of immortality. Your plan is quite clever.
Lorroakan: 'Clever' doesn't begin to describe it. What I seek is the greatest ambition possible: to defy the ultimate limitation, transcend the fate that awaits us all.
Lorroakan: When I succeed, I may look favourably upon you. If you are a friend along the way, that is.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: I know where she is. I might even be willing to tell you.

Player: I commend them to the darkness. When night falls, let them be forgotten.

conversation:
Gauntlet Edwynna: Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I'm not a refugee.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Well, do you have the means to support yourself? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. I will not pay to enter my own city.
Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed.
Player: I can take care of myself. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Gauntlet Edwynna: Right. Article 30.1.5 of the Council's Decree on Extraordinary Wartime Measures. I am confiscating that. The city thanks you for your contribution.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Your name?
Player: My name is [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
GROUP_SteelWatchers: Well met, citizen.
Narrator: *Your parasite stirs. From the construct, you feel connection. Resonance.*
Player: Remain silent.
Gauntlet Edwynna: State your business.
Wyll: My good lady. I am Wyll Ravengard. My business is the city's business.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Wyll Ravengard? Of course, of course - the city is always open to you. But I'm afraid you'll still need to comply with new protocol. By Lord Gortash's command.
Player: I'm here to enlist - figured the Fist could use a hand.
Gauntlet Edwynna: Uh-huh. Eyes open, body still.
NodeContext: "Uh-huh" as in, "Yes, I heard you and am going with it."
Player: Do as she says. Stand still.

There is NO mindmeld, because player is NOT tadpoled.

Narrator: *Behind the Watcher's gaze, a presence awakens. You are seen, you are known.*
Narrator: *Your infernal machinery seems to snap to attention, almost singing in recognition.*
Karlach: Whoa. My engine. It's almost... I don't know. Buzzing. Like it's paying attention.
Narrator: *Your party's prior transgressions are reflected in its stare, as witnessed by the cult's ever-alert scrying eyes.*
Narrator: *It has heard the howls of slaughtered goblins.*
Narrator: *It has seen the deep shadows of Grymforge, and the stone floors left bloodied.*
Narrator: *It knows the cold walls of Moonrise Towers, and the cultists who fell there.*
Narrator: *The Watcher speaks directly into your mind with a voice like poisoned honey.*
GROUP_SteelWatchers: You are marked for special treatment. Not simply an enemy of the people, but an enemy of the Absolute. Come quietly, or die.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Mindmeld with steel watcher ends
Player: Ready yourself for a fight.

Araj Oblodra: Welcome back, True Soul.
Araj Oblodra: I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: I'm listening.
Araj Oblodra: Put plainly - I'd like your blood. A vial of True Soul's blood, specifically.
Araj Oblodra: With one drop, I can brew a rather potent potion for you. The rest, I keep for myself.
Player: No, I'm not interested.
Araj Oblodra: I'm here should you change your mind.
Araj Oblodra: There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well!
Araj Oblodra: Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your vampiric friend.
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: We travel together - that's all.
Araj Oblodra: Ah, it's like that.
Araj Oblodra: Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?

Arabella: Hey - I know you! You're -
NodeContext: About to continue from 'Hey, I know you! You're - ' with a proper introduction, but is interrupted by shadow creature spawning from ground.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The creatures groan menacingly and prepare to lunge

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella casts her spell. Before the creatures can attack, vines rise from the ground and wrap around them, entangling them to her right
Shadowheart: Isn't that Arabella? The little girl Kagha nearly killed?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Arabella turns away from the trapped creature, exhausted.
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: Normally tales of stolen artefacts are tragedies - I'm glad you've bucked that trend.
Arabella: Tragedies? Them's the sad ones, right? I hope not.
Arabella: 'Specially since mum and pops - After Zevlor - When he -
Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Arabella: Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
: True
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm.
Arabella: Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: I'll find your parents - you can count on me.
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again!
Arabella: The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: I'm telling the truth: you don't want to find them.
Arabella: Then what... what is even left for me to do?
Player: It doesn't matter what you do - you'll end up dead like them, out here.

Balthazar: Ah, the interloper - and in one piece as well. Not an entirely unpromising specimen, for one naturally-born.
NodeContext: Begrudging and largely hostile, but with a hint of appreciation for the player's skill in actually making it this far.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?
Balthazar: General Thorm to you. But yes, recovering the relic is the crux of it. He commands, and I, his humble servant, fulfil that command.
Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.*
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*
Player: I need more to go on. Why is this relic so important? What does it do?
: True
Balthazar: Fine, if it'll spare me your bleating. The relic lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.
Balthazar: And spoil the surprise? I think not. But let's just say that the Nightsong was a unique specimen even before I began my work...
Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: You have resources to spare - give me something to aid my search.
: True
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...Hmm. Misplaced, it seems. You will be capable enough without it.
Player: This sounds like your problem, not mine.
Player: Keep it - this is your problem, not mine.
Balthazar: This is not a problem - it is an opportunity. And it is not a choice either - you will obey.
Player: Fine. I'll see what I can do.
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
Nightwarden Minthara: And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Madness. We need to eradicate the cult and the elder brain.
Nightwarden Minthara: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: You may be right. I'll keep an open mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: That is all I ask. And remember, I know when your mind is closed.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To impress you.

conversation:
Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: By your words, any virtue delaying patience would itself be unvirtuous.
Havkelaag: And therein lies your fault: you would have us argue in circles until the egg hatches naturally. Time we do not have.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment.
Havkelaag: Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: It is so good to see you again! I can't tell you how glad I am that you didn't enter the House without me.
Player: Who are you?
Narrator: *The figure shimmers brightly. Your words seem to have piqued her curiosity.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Who am I? It's my favourite question. I scream it into the dark while I sleep, and whisper it to my memories when I wake.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm the thing that kills you, and the only reason you're alive. Made by a promise, undone by the truth. A handshake, a hug, the first beat of a newborn's heart.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I am Hope. What little is left of her.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT
Karlach: Raphael's driven her mad. Poor soul.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'm not much of a friend to anyone anymore. But I could use a friend myself. Do you want a friend to guide you through this madhouse?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhtttt, I hear the jailor, it hears me. It'll call Raphael. Make every question count. Make some of them count twice.
Lae'zel: You must ask of the Orphic Hammer. Without it, the prince remains forever out of reach of my hungry weapon.
: NodeContext: urgent hushing and frantically getting out all of her words as quickly as possible. She's hushing the player, even though she was the one speaking
Player: What is this place?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Raphael's House of Hope. But your question was hopeless. You already knew that.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Don't waste any more words, or we'll both be sorry.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: The House is home to many things. Most will kill you, one can save you. The Hammer - the Hammer that breaks the chains. You must steal it!
Narrator: *You hear a sound like the rattle of a chain, and an agonising scream in your head as Hope flickers from view momentarily.*
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Shhhhttttt... Quiet... There it goes...
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Everyone here is mad - even you, especially me - and that makes them dangerous. But it also makes them stupid.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: I'll make you seem as ruined as the rest of the people here. A simple glamour to make you a terrible wretch.
NodeContext: very enthusiastic, casting a spell to disguise the player
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.

Player: Focus on speaking as quietly and calmly as possible.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: BEHIND YOU

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: THE ONE THAT RAT-A-TATTED THE CHAINS IN PLACE AND BROKE THE FUTURE

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you.

conversation:
Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
Nightwarden Minthara: And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: When I murder her, Bhaal will choose me in her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to put my faith in your strength than the favour of your god. After all, it is Orin and this grand deception that he chose - not you.
Nightwarden Minthara: He favours her, and she is one of the founders of this insane cult.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: Tempting, but eradicating the brain may be wiser, to put an end to this madness.
Nightwarden Minthara: Madness would be to let the Absolute's potential go to waste.
Nightwarden Minthara: The power of the enslaved elder brain could reshape the world. We could reshape the world.
Player: I fear we could lose everything if we try to take control.
Nightwarden Minthara: Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.
Nightwarden Minthara: You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
Player: Maybe I'll change your mind.
Nightwarden Minthara: The elder brain is the only thing that has ever managed to change my mind. You're welcome to try.
Nightwarden Minthara: We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
Nightwarden Minthara: There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
Nightwarden Minthara: When we killed the tieflings, at the grove, I was not in control of my actions. You do not have that excuse. So I ask you - why? Why kill them?
Player: To impress you.

Barth: I know it's stupid. It's all I have of her, is all.

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above...
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I'm so sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Vlaakith: Inquisitor W'wargaz was potent. We are impressed.
NodeContext: Vlaakith should sligjhtly overpronounce every word, think Davros from Doctor Who, each syllable drips with a kind of mad, ancient evil

Lae'zel: My queen.
Narrator: *The queen who brings conquest to the heavens, sundering planets, destroying the very stars.*
Narrator: *Hot envy swirls within. Your guts will you to author such cosmic tragedies as she has.*
Vlaakith: You are permitted to look upon me. You are invited to kneel.
Player: Kneel before Vlaakith, your queen.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player kneels, head bowed, solemn, appropriate. Vlaakith offers something resembling a smile, and gestures for the player to rise. The player rises.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Vlaakith looms in to face the player at their eye level.
Vlaakith: You bear that which is ours. But are you friend, or are you thief?
Player: Friend - I came to bring it back to you.
Gale: How generous of you - but perhaps you've forgotten we need it ourselves? That thing is keeping us safe.
Vlaakith: An unexpected servant. Your will is strong.
Vlaakith: Descendant of noble dragons - you honour us with your allyship.
Vlaakith: Extend your fealty one step further, and you will be rewarded beyond your mortal reckoning.
Vlaakith: The Astral Prism - it is corrupted.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I shall cleanse it for you, my queen. Tell me how.
InternalNodeContext: He's not altogether sure why this task is falling to the player and not to him, but also doesn't want to challenge his queen's motivations.
Vlaakith: SILENCE, W'wargaz.
Vlaakith: There is someone inside. Their mind is warped, broken - a blight.
Vlaakith: They are an agent of the Grand Design. Sent to sabotage the Astral Prism - our last defence against the return of the Illithid Empire.
Vlaakith: As long as they live, the Prism is compromised.
Vlaakith: Find the one inside and destroy them. Be aware - they are not alone, and they will appeal to your trust. They are not to be believed.
Player: So the dream visitor is inside the artefact... I can't kill them. They protect me from the Absolute.
Vlaakith: You are being LIED TO.
Vlaakith: I WILL BE OBEYED!
NodeContext: she loses herself a bit in rage here,
Player: Fine. I will go in and kill them.

Nere: Finally.
Nere: Worthless slaves. Your incompetence has been my ruin.
NodeContext: Intense but quietly so.
Nere: Nere. Does. Not. Fail.
NodeContext: ZHIL loo-NIN! Rising, seething anger. Only the last word should be louder.
Player: Stop! No more innocents will die today, Nere.
Nere: You care for the weak, True Soul. Most curious.
NodeContext: Quiet.
Player: I only see weakness in the cowardly slaver standing before me.
Nere: Yet the Absolute saw fit to bless you? I don't understand...
Nere: A test - yes, you must be. The Absolute bade you to try Nere's faith.
Nere: I will tear out your heart and feed it to the rats.
Nere: If they are indeed a True Soul, let the Absolute save them.
Player: Your god. My oath. Let us see which prevails.
Nere: You are a traitor.
Narrator: *The elder's disgust grips your head like a vice - yet he remains silent.*
Nere: Ah - another treacherous soul walks among us. Isn't that right, Brithvar?
Elder Brithvar: You been a shit since I laid eyes on you, red-eye. Go on, try and gut me. I ain't going down easy.
Nere: Direct your blade at the heretic, duergar. You shall have your coin.
Elder Brithvar: Damn right I'll have it - straight off your rotted corpse.
Nere: Nere is not without mercy, True Soul. The rat has given you a chance to earn my favour.
Nere: Strike him down. Prove your faith.
Player: Side with Nere.

Arabella: I don't see any - wait. Here they come!
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: I'd be more impressed if you'd actually killed it.
Arabella: I don't know how. I'd kill 'em all if I could. I - I just want my mum and pops.
Arabella: We followed Zevlor out here. Then he - he -
Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Arabella: Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
: False
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*

Arabella: Fine. Whatever. I don't need you - I'll find them myself!
Player: You're going to get yourself killed. I'll find them, all right?
Arabella: Thanks so much. I knew you'd help me again!
Arabella: The vines won't last forever. I don't - I don't s'pose I can stay with you?
NodeContext: Slightly unsure of herself.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: Muster some kindness for once. Offer her shelter.

Karlach: Hold up. One more step, and I put a bolt through your eye.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: stands, holding the crossbow in one hand, her other hand pressed to a wound on the left of her stomach. She appraises the player.
Karlach: No sudden movements, or you're dead.
Karlach: You looking for me?
Player: No, but I see you're hurt - let me help.
Karlach: Hurt or not, I won't miss - lung, heart, arse or eye. Take your pick.
Karlach: Tell me what you're doing here. Now.
Player: If you keep pointing that thing at me this is going to end badly for you.
: True
Karlach: Hm. If you bite as hard as you bark, we might get along. I might even have a job for you.

Karlach: I'm in a tight spot - might not be able to get out of it alone.
Player: Fight your own battles.
Karlach: Oh, I have. The kind of battles a cub like you sees in their nightmares.
Player: You've got my attention - what's your story?
Karlach: All right. Come on over here. But fair warning - you might find this hard to believe.
Karlach: I'm a fugitive. I escaped the Hells, and the bastards who were holding me there are trying to take me back.
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: That doesn't sound ideal.
Karlach: It's not - it's a shitting catastrophe. But at least I'm out.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: I didn't see you aboard. Where were you?
Karlach: I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: Stowing away aboard a mind flayer's nautiloid? Pretty stupid.
Karlach: If you'd seen as much of hell as I have, you'd rather have a flayer's tentacles up your arse than stay.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: What makes you so important to them?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: Judging by the wound, I'm guessing they already found you.
Karlach: Yeah. Not far from here - gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse.
Karlach: I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.
Player: I'll look into it.

Wyll: Agh, Hells! I was hoping you wouldn't notice I was gone.
Player: Of course I noticed. It was no party without you.
Wyll: Really? I'm honoured.
Wyll: In truth, I don't feel in a festive mood, and didn't want to cast a grey cloud over the night.
Wyll: I'm a devil. I love the people from the grove, but I unsettle them deep down.
Wyll: As I seem to unsettle everyone nowadays.
Wyll: You don't want a devil at your party.
Wyll: Horns this sharp will pop the balloons, you see. And the guests won't take kindly to scars quite so monstrous.
Player: To our kind, those features just make you more attractive.
Wyll: You pull them off far more finely than I do.
Wyll: But off with you. This is your day! Have a dance. Enjoy the music.

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.

Karlach: Anyhow. Piss off.
Player: I met the people looking for you. They say you're a killer - a fiend.
Karlach: And you believe them? Those bastards are trying to feed you a crock of shit.
Karlach: Don't sweat it - devils are tricky fuckers. They can't breathe without lying.
Player: If you're not a fiend, what are you?
Karlach: Are you demented? I'm a tiefling - same as you. More or less.
Karlach: I guess they told you I bite the heads off babies, and paint myself in their blood.
Karlach: Truth's not quite so exciting. Come on over and I'll tell you the whole story.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: That doesn't sound ideal.
Karlach: It's not - it's a shitting catastrophe. But at least I'm out.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...
NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us
Player: That was terrifying.
Karlach: That was one of my good days - the bad ones would knock you sick.
Karlach: Now tell me what you just did to me before I make sure you can never do it again.
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: I didn't see you aboard. Where were you?
Karlach: I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did.
Karlach: The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: What makes you so important to them?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: How can I help?
Karlach: A gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse, not far from here.
Karlach: I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.
Player: I'll look into it.

Ptaris: You - you don't look like them. You look like me. Who are you?
Player: A githyanki? What are you doing down here?
Ptaris: I am not a githyanki. Do not call me that!
Ptaris: I am Ptaris. And I am good.
Ptaris: Father was bad. They all were. I tried to make them better, but they were not strong enough. They lacked resolve.
Player: Don't worry - I'm not here to judge.
Ptaris: Everyone judges, and everyone must be judged. This is the only way to know if we are good enough. Father was not.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: I like to think so.
Ptaris: If you only think, then you do not know.
Ptaris: The Ptarian Code must be obeyed. This is the only way to be sure. Do you follow it?
Player: No one code can define goodness. It's impossible.
Ptaris: Only a bad person would say that. And that's what you are.
Ptaris: I know what you did to me. I see the memory of it, right there in your head.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: I never should have saved you. But I'm happy to rectify my mistake.
Player: You would have been destroyed if not for me. I saved you.
: True
Ptaris: You were trying to save me? I - I don't understand.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: What wrong has this man done to deserve such torture?
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: I have read your treatise. Initiate the final lesson, or die by my hand.
: True
Malus Thorm: The final lesson. Yes. For to teach absence, one must become absent.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

He Who Was: Indeed. One whose secrets are not for your ears. Be on your way.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Death often comes for a reason. I've killed before, does that make me a murderer?
He Who Was: Depends. Did those you kill trust you? Care for you?
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: I doubt you're here out of the goodness of your heart.
He Who Was: I have no heart.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: Kill the dead. Kill the killed dead. Kill the killed dead again and again.
Narrator: *Your mind swoons with possibilities, this blessed loon may murder the same soul as many times as he wishes.*
He Who Was: No. I seek only justice - not murderous deviancy.
He Who Was: I offer you a chance to avenge this murderer's victims. Will you take it?
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you?
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath.
Alfira: I had to watch my friends, people who can barely hold a sword, try to fight a pack of murderous zealots.
Alfira: All I could do was run.
Player: Only fools fight an ambush. Better to live and strike another day - preferably to the neck.
Alfira: That means a lot, coming from you. You always seem to take everything in your stride.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: 'When the night is dark, stars shine brightest.' So keep on shining. It's going to be all right.
Alfira: 'Heart's Requiem', right? The hero survives a war and rebuilds her life - stronger than ever. A tale worth remembering - especially now.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

Lorroakan: Mark my words: the Nightsong is mine. With or without your help, she will ascend to her grand fate here, in this tower.
Lorroakan: You can get very rich along the way, or let someone else take what's rightfully yours. Choose wisely.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap.
Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I seek a certain rare tome - concerning Karsus.
Lorroakan: You're quite in luck, then - see Tolna downstairs. One such tome is amongst our rarest books.
Lorroakan: But enough of dusty history - I look to the future.
Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face.
Lorroakan: Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.
Lorroakan: Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him.
Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: I know where she is. I might even be willing to tell you.
Minsc: You would betray Dame Aylin? Be you faithless, or simply foolish?
Nightwarden Minthara: Surrendering a powerful ally to this preening wizard does not seem wise.
Shadowheart: She deserves better than to fall into his clutches. I owe her, in a sense.
Lorroakan: Good. Then you'll have no trouble fulfilling the contract to bring the Nightsong here.
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.
Lorroakan: Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him.
Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: I'll tell her to come here - just to give her the satisfaction of ripping you to shreds.

Gauntlet Edwynna: Halt! By orders of Lord Gortash, refugees are no longer allowed in the city. Turn around.
Player: I have urgent business in the city.

Gauntlet Edwynna: Wyll Ravengard? Of course, of course - the city is always open to you. But I'm afraid you'll still need to comply with new protocol. By Lord Gortash's command.

: True

conversation:
Narrator: *Your father, once the Grand Duke, now a pawn in the Absolute's game. Your infected minds smoulder in each others' presence.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My dearest boy. The Hells have touched you. But you've come to me - just as Gortash said you would.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Father and son, unstoppable generals. Together, we will usher in a new dawn.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*
Player: Connect with Ravengard's parasite to seek information about Florrick.
: True
Narrator: *Within Ravengard's memories, you find Counsellor Florrick. She is confined in a cell, right here in Wyrm's Rock.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found her.*
Player: Leave the duke's mind unexplored.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready?
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: Don't you understand? You are infected with an illithid parasite.
Narrator: *For a brief moment, uncertainty clouds his mind, then dissipates. The Astral Prism vibrates in concord.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: What nonsense is this. I...
Narrator: *The Prism quivers once more. Ravengard falters.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: ...help me...
Narrator: *Ravengard's eyes grow empty again. Once again, he speaks coolly and calmly.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: As I said. Baldur's Gate will ascend. Toril's first and only Grand City.
Player: Call on your tadpole. Explore Ravengard's uncertainty.
: True
Narrator: *First comes a vision of terror. The city of Baldur's Gate taken by illithids.*

Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I've seen a lot of nasty ambushes in my time - but that sounds among the worst. I'm sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Only the strong survive. You want to live? Focus on yourself.
Alfira: ...If you say so. But not everyone is as strong as you are.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: Don't worry, I'll find them.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I don't wish to study, only to lift the curse on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: They need a better subject to practise on first. Not a student, but a master.
: True
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am a scholar, this is true - just not in the study of torture.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am but a fumbling squire before a master swordsman. Please, demonstrate so that I might learn.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Karlach: What the fuck is this loon talking about.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: I have read your treatise. Initiate the final lesson, or die by my hand.
: True
Malus Thorm: The final lesson. Yes. For to teach absence, one must become absent.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: I am no student, I seek knowledge of the curse. It is a blight on this land.
Malus Thorm: A curse? Nay, a cure that leads to the very pinnacle of being:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: They need a better subject to practise on first. Not a student, but a master.
: True
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Karlach: Anyhow. Piss off.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: You said yourself, devils are tricksters. I don't believe a word of this.
Karlach: You're picking the wrong side here - those bastards aren't what they claim to be.
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*
Karlach: Ster'ca. What was that? You were inside my head...

Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: I didn't see you aboard. Where were you?
Karlach: I boarded in Avernus - that ship was my way out.
Player: You were expecting the ship?
Karlach: No - I just saw a chance and I took it.
Karlach: That ship could have been heading for Sigil or Limbo for all I cared - anything was better than staying.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: What makes you so important to them?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: Judging by the wound, I'm guessing they already found you.
Karlach: Yeah. Not far from here - gang of cultists cornered me in an abandoned tollhouse.
Karlach: I took out a couple, but I need them all dead.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.

Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.

Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

: True
