Player: No. In fact, maybe I'll free the one inside.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Welcome, adventurer! I take it you're new to Rivington.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: No doubt you came here to choose from my fine selection of weapons?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Yes, I seem to have it all. Clubs, swords, maces, bows. Cutting and gutting galore.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Why don't we see if we can find the perfect weapon for you?
Player: How will you know my perfect weapon?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: I provide a personalised service for my customers. To make sure the weapon I choose is the perfect fit.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Tell me, how do you like to kill?
Player: It flows through me as raw inspiration, I never know what my next kill will look like.
Nightwarden Minthara: That is why you make for such delightful company.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Such imagery. You are an artist with a weapon in your hand, I can tell.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: And when you kill someone, what do you feel?
Player: Exhilarated beyond compare. It is my purpose.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: It is a pleasure, isn't it? Warm and sweet and sticky.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: One more question, if you'll humour me.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Do you think you could turn your weapon on those closest to you?
Player: I do all I can to keep my loved ones safe from my blade.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you?
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: I take what I'm due and I don't look back.
Alfira: That sounds quite freeing - but I don't have that option, I'm afraid.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: Don't worry, I'll find them.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Enough, Wulbren! Gortash enslaved us, forced us to build his Steel Watchers - but no more.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What about Gortash? What if he forces you to build up his Steel Watch once more?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: I will be long gone from this wretched city before that happens. I am no threat - I am... nothing.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes.
Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Wulbren, don't make me burn you to a crisp. Walk away.
Player: LEAVE, LITTLE WULBREN. OR DIE.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: My dearest boy. The Hells have touched you. But you've come to me - just as Gortash said you would.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Father and son, unstoppable generals. Together, we will usher in a new dawn.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Florrick chose shadow over light. Her betrayal burned deeper than the fires of Avernus.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: She's been punished for her lies. Don't let her get to you.
Narrator: *The Duke wants to keep Florrick's location a secret. Little does he know that you've already found and freed her.*

: True

: False
Narrator: *You are unable to penetrate Ravengard's mind.*
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The sun rises, True Soul. Are you ready?

Player: Gortash is a tyrant. This 'new dawn' is a lie.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Why do you say this? Only the shadows would name the sun a tyrant.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Faerûn suffers in darkness. Tyr has abandoned us; Helm's eye has strayed.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: And it will be Gortash who ignites the final spark.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: By the gods, what have they made of the city's great hero?

Gauntlet Edwynna: No refugees. It is decreed.

Karlach: Could have sworn I told you to piss off. Maybe I imagined it.

Player: If you're not a fiend, what are you?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~[reuse]The player approaches Karlach
Karlach: I'm a fugitive - escaped from the Hells, and those bastards are trying to take me back.
Player: I visited Avernus recently - seemed delightful.
Karlach: Do you find this funny?
Narrator: *As she winces, agony shoots through you, as if your bodies share the same wound.*
Narrator: *Then you're lost in visions of demonic armies, as you tear through a landscape of fire and blood.*
Narrator: *The Blood War. You saw it from above as the nautiloid passed through Avernus - this woman was on the frontline.*

NodeContext: ster'ca (stir-KA (very harsh KA)) is a curse word in infernal language. She's shocked, a little afraid of us

Karlach: Yeah - with distinction.
Karlach: Now tell me what you just did to me before I make sure you can never do it again.
Player: It wasn't me - it's the parasites from the mind flayer ship. They connected us.
Karlach: Hold on a minute - you were on that ship? With the tentacles, and the worms?
Karlach: I didn't think anyone else had survived.
Player: You must have got clear of the crash site in a hurry.
Karlach: You're lucky I did.
Karlach: The place would have been crawling with cultists if I'd stuck around - and they'd have dragged us all back to Avernus.
Karlach: And I'll be going straight back if those imp-fuckers catch me.
Player: What makes you so important to them?
Karlach: I was a prisoner, forced to fight in the Blood War - the eternal battle between bad and worse.
Karlach: Most souls in Avernus are just meat for the grinder. But not me.
Karlach: I held my own. More than. Turns out I've got a knack for killing demons - and I enjoy it. That made me a valuable asset.
Karlach: Devils don't like to lose their assets.
Player: So you want me to kill the people hunting you?
Karlach: Yeah. Can you handle it?
Player: Yes.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?

Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style

He Who Was: Stay your hand, and be on your way. I'll not raise mine against you.

: False

Player: It is an honour to meet one of the Raven Queen's scions. What brings you here?
He Who Was: For your kind to know Her ways is rare. You will suit the task at hand well.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: It sounds like she must be punished - thoroughly.
He Who Was: You see it as I do.

NodeContext: Whispered

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You also killed Sarth Baretha. She was formidable.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: How do you know so much about me?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Some of your species say knowledge is power. They are wrong. Knowledge is everything.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: We took an interest in you when you became involved with this 'Absolute' cult. A pestilence of infected slaves - the first symptom of the Grand Design in action.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But you are lucky - that weapon you carry is the solution. I have heard it from Queen Vlaakith herself.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Hand it over.
Player: I thought the Grand Design was a ghaik philosophy, not an actual plan.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The Grand Design is what all ghaik seek. The restoration of the Illithid Empire, which spanned the entirety of the multiverse.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: For centuries, their elder brains sought to bring back their dominion. Every plot they hatched, we stopped. But now, they are close to succeeding.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Never before could they pause ceremorphosis. Never before could they let the infection spread undetected.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Imagine that everywhere. Wants, needs, choice - all would cease to be.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Everything rendered unto the ghaik.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: So. The weapon. Please.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.
Player: I won't let you take it.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: You can't trust him, Lae'zel. Follow my lead. I will choose the right path.
: True
Lae'zel: Tsk - tsk - tsk'va! I hate that you speak the truth.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.

Alfira: All I could do was run.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.

Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.

Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.

Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: In my experience, torture is usually more pain and less proselytising.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Aradin: All I've got's the contract. Can show you where we turned back, if you feel like dying.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: What wrong has this man done to deserve such torture?
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Shadowheart: A stinging truth - but a truth nonetheless.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: I thought I smelled a Selûnite.
Isobel: At your service.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: Nod. Better to humour her than make an enemy of all in this place. Lady Shar will understand.
Isobel: Refreshingly pragmatic of you. I sense Shar has offered some amount of protection to you already, but... well, no harm in extra precaution - even from a Selûnite.
Player: Silently petition Lady Shar for guidance.
Narrator: *She offers you nothing.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The poignant tedium of your story?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Smile and take Wyll's hand.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.
Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: A beautiful story. I'm glad you told it to me.
Wyll: I was hoping you'd think so.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?
Player: Yes, yes, yes!
Wyll: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.
Narrator: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*
Wyll: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A devil's plaything awaiting a future in the Hells.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: The elder brain?
Wyll: Maybe. But I think the right answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: Go on - I'll follow.

Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?
Wyll: I did. But also to see something else:
Wyll: Me.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.
Wyll: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Flames ignite Mizora and her two companions. Mizora's voice echos outward as if amplified by the Hells themselves.
Mizora: Wyll Ravengard. A choice is before you.
Mizora: Option one. I show you the way to your father. I guarantee him no harm except that from you and your allies. And you pledge your soul to me and the archdevil Zariel in a pact eternal.
Mizora: Option two. I break your pact. You are freed from your duty but retain your devil form. Your father dies by his enemy's hand.
Mizora: Name your sacrifice.
Karlach: Bloody Zariel. I won't let her take Wyll!

Wyll: Mizora, you arsehole.
Mizora: Choose.

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first.
Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him.
Zevlor: Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor.

Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.

Player: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?

Zevlor: But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.
Player: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer.
Player: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Wyll: It's funny.
Wyll: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.
Wyll: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.
Wyll: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.
Player: You, yourself?
Wyll: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:
Wyll: Time.
Wyll: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.
Wyll: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.
Wyll: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.
Wyll: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.
Wyll: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -
Wyll: If just for a moment.
Wyll: Come, let me show you.
Player: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. Wyll: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.
Wyll: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.
Wyll: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.
Wyll: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.
Player: A beautiful story. I'm glad you told it to me.
Wyll: I was hoping you'd think so.
Wyll: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -
Wyll: And who I want at my side as it passes.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.
Wyll: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.

Wyll: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?

conversation:
Counsellor Florrick: Godsdamned hypocrite.
Counsellor Florrick: The Blade of Frontiers - all pomp and empty oaths. The Sword Coast's most dashing fraud.
NodeContext: Please include Florricking Spitting (motion and sound) before delivering the line.
Counsellor Florrick: I trusted you. I believed in you.
Wyll: Florrick, what are you on about - what is this?
Counsellor Florrick: Lady Mizora told me everything. How you slaughtered your own father, how you crave his power.
Counsellor Florrick: I thought you were going to save him, but you abused his current state to get rid of him!
Counsellor Florrick: You mean to make the city bow to you and you alone!
Wyll: That meddling ghoul. Florrick, I -
Counsellor Florrick: Save it. My duty is to Baldur's Gate - and it holds no place for Ravengard's treacherous spawn.
Player: Ravengard could still be alive. And we intend to save him.
: True
Counsellor Florrick: At ease.
Counsellor Florrick: By the living gods, I believe you.
Counsellor Florrick: What darkness has fallen upon us.
Counsellor Florrick: Wyll, there's something you must know. I should've told you sooner, but I'd hoped somehow your father would return to us.
Counsellor Florrick: He knew about the Absolute. I thought little of it at first - but he realised the danger before anyone else did.
Counsellor Florrick: He understood that if the cult were successful in raising an army, Baldur's Gate would be doomed.
Counsellor Florrick: Before the Absolutists abducted him, he told me that should he fall, I must seek you out and give you this message.
Counsellor Florrick: Your father trained you in the ways of the great champions. You are to use those lessons to wake the wyrm under the city. He is oathbound to answer your call and come to our aid.
Player: A wyrm? Are you saying there's a dragon living under the city?
Counsellor Florrick: A bronze dragon, yes. He sleeps beneath us even now, awaiting a hero to rouse him.
Counsellor Florrick: The wyrm goes by many names. Ansur. The Waiting Storm. The Heart of the Gate.
Counsellor Florrick: He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once.
Counsellor Florrick: Since then the city faced countless threats - but the Baldurians overcame them all. There was never any need to call upon the wyrm. But this time, things are different.
Counsellor Florrick: This is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. Your father was right - we need Ansur's help. With him gone, the wyrm's awakening now falls to you.
Counsellor Florrick: The duke gave me this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale.
Counsellor Florrick: Let it set the path before you.
Player: Your faith in Wyll is well-founded. We will seek the wyrm and ask for his help.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Wyll.

Player: Say nothing.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: My son, you sold your soul to save Baldur's Gate - and I cast you out for it.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: You gave yourself to the Hells' eternal fires so I might walk free.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: By the gods, can you ever forgive me?

Duke Ulder Ravengard: You are a better man than most, and a better son than I deserve. I'll yet make amends, but -

Duke Ulder Ravengard: I didn't despair because the city has a secret guardian, a wyrm that sleeps beneath. He can be called upon in times of great need.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: He promised Balduran he'd protect the city if ever its existence was threatened. But just the once.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Since then, the city has faced countless threats, but we always overcame. There was never a need to call on the wyrm - until now.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: The Absolute is the greatest threat Baldur's Gate ever faced. The wyrm must be awakened - and the task falls to you.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Take this - 'The Legend of Ansur'. An ancient epic, ill-remembered, dismissed as a mere tale.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player walks toward their bedroll/sleeping area.
Narrator: *You are enveloped in myriad sensations, all at once. Flaming desire and icy despair; the strength of iron and the haze of thick swamp mist.*
Mizora: The Nine Hells of Baator. The ultimate torment, some souls would say.
Mizora: Tsk. Those souls lack imagination.
Player: Show me more.
Mizora: With pleasure. As long as you're willing to give in.
Mizora: A banquet lies before you. Why should you not gorge?
Player: Give in to the infernal sensations.
Mizora: I'm going to show you the true wages of your sin.
Narrator: *Pure lust courses through your veins and plucks at your flesh. You don't know what you want, only that you want it.*
Mizora: You feel it, don't you? Primal hunger, irrepressible decadence. Forget the heavens - this is paradise.
Mizora: Let me show you.
Player: I'm ready. Bring me the pleasures of the Hells.
Narrator: *An inferno engulfs you. Your lust blazes hot.*
Mizora: Do you feel it? Avernus. Where Hells' legions march, screaming their rage. Where the Styx collects the blood of the fallen.
Mizora: Where your rightful mistress shoulders the burdens of perpetual war.
Mizora: Reach out. Have a taste.
Player: Gorge on the River of Blood. Relish its flavour.
Narrator: *The flavour is exquisite as spiced wine, terrible as rotting offal. It does not quench your lust - it only stokes it.*

The player makes a fist, the flame extinguishes, but in doing so a new flood of sensation rushes into their core. Their back and neck arch slightly as they breath deep.
Mizora: Don't worry, pet. I won't leave 'til you're fully satisfied.
Mizora: Dis, the blackened elysium. Minauros, the rotting bog. The molten seas and soil of Phlegethos. Stygia, the frozen ocean.
Mizora: Choose a Hell. Have your fill.
Player: The polluted swamps of Minauros.
Narrator: *You inhale the oily clouds of Minauros' stink. It is the stench of dead lovers and sour romances. It is the unwantable - but you still lust for more.*

The player extends both arms out toward the flames, palms down. Their eyes close as they connect with Mizora's hellish offerings.

She watches as the pleasure rides out the sensations.

Mizora: One last choice, and starve no longer.
Mizora: Malbolge, the desolation. The forgotten ruins of Maladomini. Cania and its mountains of ice. Or Nessus, the seat of infernal power.
Player: Cania, realm of glaciers.
Narrator: *Ice. Its embrace is tighter than any you've known. It is cold, but you want colder. You want total zero.*

The player player rotates their palms upward, and look up, basking in the arcane sensory experience.
